name: Onyx
comment:
Onyx is a digital modeling of a real custom-made tube amplifier with three channels combined and separate pre and power amps. The Onyx offers control over a vast landscape of sounds: the gain knob, in combination with the clipping stage, creates unique distortions that range from sparkly clean all the way to modern metal. Tweak the character knob to alter the voice of the amplifier from warm to bright.

Features:
Modeled by VeJa Plugins
label: Onyx

name: Calf Envelope Filter
comment:
The Calf Envelope Filter is an envelope filter which increases with volume, meaning the louder you play, the higher the filter.

Features:
Modeled by Calf
label: Envelope filter

name: Calf Flanger
comment:
The Calf Flanger is a simple stereo flanger featuring linear interpolation. For those who dislike the typical “zipper noise” known to flangers, this one might be worth a try! 

Features:
Modeled by Calf
label: Flanger

name: Calf Phaser
comment:
A simple stereo phaser with all typical settings. The Calf Phaser provides a LFO reset button for consistent song playback. 

Features:
Modeled by Calf
label: Phaser

name: Calf Saturator
comment:
The Calf Saturator is a universal distortion tool that can act as a guitar distortion as well as a harmonics generator. You can achieve great flexibility in your sound thanks to some filtering before and after distortion as well as some gapless adjustment between 2nd and 3rd harmonics. 

Features:
Modeled by Tom Szilagyi and Markus Schimdt
label: Saturator

name: amsynth
comment:
The AmSynth is a synth with a classic subtractive synthesizer topology. It features Dual oscillators, a resonant filter, a dual ADSR and a LFO. If you’re not into turning a bunch of fancy knobs and just want to plug and play, give the presets of this synth a go, it has a broad variety of sounds including some classic synths and some funky noises!

Features:
Modeled by Nick Dowell
label: amsynth

name: Kars
comment: Simple karplus-strong plucked string synth.
label: Kars

name: MVerb
comment: Studio quality reverb, provides a practical demonstration of Dattorro’s figure-of-eight reverb structure.
label: MVerb

name: Nekobi
comment:
The Nekobi generator is based on the legendary Roland TB-303© (*).
This polemic bass-synthesizer got quite some critiques in its early days. Soon the public realised its incredible fit to trance, house and EDM music like no other device at the time. Loyal to its inspiration, the Nekobi is a monophonic synthesizer, which means only one note can be played at a time.

Features:
Modeled by FalkTX & Sean Bolton

(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
The Roland TB-303© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”
label: Nekobi

name: Ping Pong Pan
comment:
The Ping Pong Pan fades the sound from left to right. 
It features 2 knobs. ‘Frequency’ controls how fast the directional change happens and ‘Width’ tells the amount of signal that gets faded. When the knob is set to 100%, audio on the left is muted when audio on the right is at full volume.

Features:
Modeled by FalkTX
label: Ping Pong Pan

name: Auto-wah
comment:
The auto-wah is a combination of an envelope follower and a resonant low pass filter.
For increasing sound levels, both the frequency and the bandwidth of the filter will increase. The intensity is controlled by 'Drive'.
For a normal wah, use an expression pedal to control 'Frequency' and set 'Drive' to zero.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP
label: Wah

name: CS Chorus 1
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.

Based on a CSound orchestra file by Sean Costello. There are two low frequency oscillators, each having three outputs that are 120 degrees apart in phase. The summed outputs modulate three delay lines.
Make sure the static delay (first parameter) is at least equal to the sum of the two modulation depths.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP
label: CS Chorus 1

name: CS Chorus 2
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.

Functionally identical to variant 1, but upsamples the input to the delay lines in an attempt to mitigate the errors produced by the linear interpolation at the output.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP
label: CS Chorus 2

name: CS Phaser 1 with LFO
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.

Similar to CS Phaser 1, but the external modulation has been replaced by a built-in LFO.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP
label: CS Phaser 1+LFO

name: reverb
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.
This is a stereo reverb plugin based on the well-known G Reverb. One might think that this reverb was designed for the guitar - but it does wonders used on vocals.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP
label: Reverb

name: Triple chorus
comment:
A Chorus effect with three separate outputs. Pan L, C and R for a nice stereo effect.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP
label: Triple Chorus

name: Freakclip
comment: Clipped Filter
label: Freakclip

name: Freaktail
comment: The tail of a Reverb, can be used in combination with Prefreak to complete the reverb
label: Freaktail

name: Granulator
comment: A realtime granulator plays small chunks of audio in the delay time setted
label: Granulator

name: Prefreak
comment:
PreFreak offers a blurry pre-delay; can be used in combination with FreakTail to complete the reverb in full-effect.

Features:
Modeled by Freaked
label: Prefreak

name: setBfree DSP Tonewheel Organ
comment:
The setBfree is a MIDI-controlled software synthesizer designed to imitate the sound and properties of the electromechanical organs and sound modification devices that brought worldwide fame to the names and products of Laurens Hammond and Don Leslie. 

Features:
Modeled by Robin Gareus
label: setBfree

name: setBfree Whirl Speaker
comment:
A rotating loudspeaker emulator designed to imitate the sound of device that brought world-wide fame to the name of Don Leslie.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Whirl Speaker

name: Autotune
comment:
The AT1 is used to correct pitch within the vocal range and features a few different modes. The first one is the Auto mode - with this mode, the pitch will automatically be bent to the nearest true exact semitone. When selecting the MIDI mode, the pitch will be bent to the incoming midi note. The last mode is the manual mode, in which the keyboard on the pedalboard can be used.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Autotune

name: x42-eq - Parametric Equalizer Mono
comment:
A very complete EQ with visual response.
Featuring 4 bands, highpass and lowpass filters, you can now use your stomp box in order to tweak each edge of your sound as you like it.

Features:
Modeled by Robin Gareus
label: Parametric EQ

name: x42-eq - Parametric Equalizer Stereo
comment:
A very complete stereo EQ with visual response.
Featuring 4 bands, highpass and lowpass filters, you can now use your stomp box in order to tweak each edge of your sound as you like it.

Features:
Modeled by Robin Gareus
label: Parametric EQ ST

name: MIDI Clock Generator
comment:
A MIDI clock generator with optional host transport synchronization.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Clock

name: MIDI CC to Note
comment:
MIDI CC to Note enables you to convert MIDI control change messages to note-on/off messages. Note off is queued 10 msec later.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI CC to Note

name: MIDI Channel Filter
comment:
MIDI channel filter. Only data for selected channel shall pass. This filter only affects midi-data which is channel relevant (ie note-on/off, control and program changes, key and channel pressure and pitch bend). MIDI-SYSEX and Realtime message are always passed on.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Chn Filter

name: MIDI Channel Map
comment:
MIDI Channel Map enables you to rewrite midi-channel numbers. This filter only affects midi-data which is channel relevant (ie note-on/off, control and program changes, key and channel pressure and pitch bend). MIDI-SYSEX and Realtime message are always passed thru unmodified.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Chn Map

name: MIDI Enforce Scale
comment:
MIDI Enforce Scale enables you to filter note-on/off events depending on musical scale. If the key is changed note-off events of are sent for all active off-key notes.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Force Scale

name: MIDI Event Filter
comment:
MIDI Event Filter is a notch style message filter. It enables you to suppress specific messages. For flexible note-on/off range see also 'keyrange' and 'velocityrange'.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Event Flt.

name: MIDI Key-Range Filter
comment:
MIDI Key Range Filter lets you define a range of allowed midi notes. Notes-on/off events outside the allowed range are discarded. If the range changes, note-off events are sent to currently active notes that end up outside the valid range.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Key/Range

name: MIDI Keysplit
comment:
MIDI Keysplit enables you to change midi-channel number depending on note. The plugin keeps track of transposed midi-notes and sends note-off events accordingly if the range is changed even if a note is active.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Keysplit

name: MIDI CC Map
comment:
MIDI CC Map enables you to change one control message into another. Combined with MIDI Scale CC Value, it allows you to modify/scale the actual value.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI CC Map

name: MIDI Note/Channel Map
comment:
A 12-tone channel map which allows you to change midi-channel per note.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Key/Chn Map

name: MIDI Note Transpose
comment:
MIDI Note Transpose is a flexible 12-tone map which allows you to map a note within an octave to another note in the same octave-range +- 12 semitones. Alternatively, notes can also be disabled. The settings can be changed dynamically: Note-on/off events will be sent accordingly.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Note Transp

name: MIDI Chord
comment:
This harmonizer creates chords from a single (fundamental) note in a given musical scale. The scale as well as intervals can be automated freely (currently held chords will change). Note-ons are latched, for multiple/combined chords only single note-on/off will be triggered for the duration of the combined chords. If a off-scale note is given, it will be passed through - no chord is allocated.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Chord

name: MIDI Delayline
comment:
MIDI Delayline enables you to delay all MIDI events by a given time which is shown as BPM and beats. If the delay includes a random factor, this effect takes care of always keeping note on/off events sequential regardless of the randomization.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Delayline

name: MIDI Channel Unisono
comment:
MIDI Channel Filter Unisono enables you to duplicate MIDI events from one channel to another.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Chn Unisono

name: MIDI Strum
comment:
A midi arpeggio effect intended to simulate strumming a stringed instrument (e.g. guitar). A chord is 'collected' and the single notes of the chord are played back, spread out over time. The 'Note Collect Timeout' allows for the effect to be played live with midi-keyboard.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Strum

name: MIDI Chromatic Transpose
comment:
A chromatic transpose of midi notes and key-pressure. If an inversion point is set, the scale is mirrored around this point before transposing. Notes that end up outside the valid range 0..127 are discarded.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Transpose

name: MIDI Monophonic Legato
comment:
MIDI Monophonic Legato allows you to hold a note until the next one arrives. In order to switch it off, replay the same note again.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Mono Legato

name: MIDI Remove Active Sensing
comment:
A filter made to block all active sensing events. Active sensing messages are optional MIDI messages intended to be sent repeatedly to tell a receiver that a connection is alive, however they can clutter up the MIDI channel or be inadvertently recorded when dumping raw MIDI data to disk.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI No Act Sens

name: MIDI Duplicate Blocker
comment:
MIDI Duplicate Blocker enables you to filter out overlapping notes on/off and duplicate messages.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Dup. Block

name: MIDI Note to CC
comment:
MIDI Note to CC allows you to convert only MIDI note-on messages to control change messages (ignored in toggle mode).

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Note to CC

name: MIDI Note Toggle
comment:
With MIDI Note Toggle, play a note to turn it on and play it again to turn it off.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Note Toggle

name: MIDI N-Tap Delay
comment:
MIDI N-Tap Delay repeats notes N times, where N is either a fixed number or unlimited as long as a given key is pressed. BPM and delay-time variable allows tempo-ramps. On every repeat the given velocity-adjustment is added or subtracted, the result is clamped between 1 and 127.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI N-Tap Delay

name: MIDI Simple Channel Filter
comment:
Simple MIDI channel filter. Only data for selected channels may pass. This filter only affects midi-data which is channel relevant (ie note-on/off, control and program changes, key and channel pressure and pitchbend). MIDI-SYSEX and Realtime message are always passed on. See also 'MIDI Channel Map' filter.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI 1 Chn Flt.

name: MIDI Quantization
comment:
Live event quantization. This filter aligns incoming MIDI events to a fixed time-grid. Since the effect operates on a live-stream, it will introduce latency: events will be delayed until the next 'tick'.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Quantize

name: MIDI Velocity Randomization
comment:
MIDI Velocity Randomization lets you randomize the velocity of MIDI notes (both note on and note off).

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Rand Vel.

name: MIDI Scale CC Value
comment:
MIDI Scale CC Value enables you to modify the value (data-byte) of a MIDI control change message.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI CC Scale

name: MIDI Sostenuto
comment:
MIDI Sostenuto delays note-off messages by a given time, emulating a piano sostenuto pedal. When the pedal is released, note-off messages that are queued will be sent immediately.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Sostenuto

name: MIDI Velocity-Range Filter
comment:
MIDI Velocity-Range Filter will filter MIDI note-on events according to velocity. Note-on events outside the allowed range are discarded. If a Note-off is received for a note that was previously filtered, it is also not passed though.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Vel. Flt.

name: MIDI Velocity Adjust
comment:
With MIDI Velocity Adjust, change the velocity of note events with separate controls for Note-on and Note-off. The input range 1 - 127 is mapped to the range between Min and Max. If Min is greater than Max, the range is reversed. The offsets value is added to the velocity event after mapping the Min/Max range.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Vel. Adjust

name: MIDI Generator
comment:
A MIDI generator that plays fixed, predefined sequences. Select your key and play around with the BPM.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Generator

name: Level Meter
comment: Numeric Audio Signal Level Meter (DPM with 15dB/sec falloff + RMS meter)
label: Level Meter

name: Spectrum Analyzer
comment: Crude Spectrum Analyzer
label: SpectrumAnalyzer

name: MIDI Timecode (MTC) Generator
comment:
A MIDI Timecode generator with optional host transport synchronization.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: MIDI Timecode

name: MIDI Step Sequencer16x8
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 16 notes and 8 steps.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Step Seq. 16x8

name: MIDI Step Sequencer32x8
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 32 notes and 8 steps.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Step Seq. 32x8

name: MIDI Step Sequencer8x16
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 16 notes and 8 steps.
Also available in 8x8 and 8x4 versions.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Step Seq. 8x16

name: MIDI Step Sequencer8x4
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 8 notes and 4 steps.
Also available in 8x8 and 8x4 versions.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Step Seq. 8x4

name: MIDI Step Sequencer8x8
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 8 notes and 8 steps.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Step Seq. 8x8

name: TinyGain Mono
comment:
A mono gain-stage with the range of +/-20dB and additional mute-control.
The gain control is low-pass filtered at 20Hz to prevent zipper noise.
The level display shows digital-peak (dBFS) of the output signal
(rise-time: immediate, falloff: 15dB/sec).
Also Available in a stereo version.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: TinyGain Mono

name: TinyGain Stereo
comment:
A stereo gain-stage with the range of +/-20dB and additional mute-control.
The gain control is low-pass filtered at 20Hz to prevent zipper noise.
The level display shows digital-peak (dBFS) of the output signal
(rise-time: immediate, falloff: 15dB/sec).
Also Available in a mono version.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: TinyGain Stereo

name: Instrument Tuner
comment: Musical instrument tuner with strobe characteristics
label: Tuna Tuner

name: Stereo X-Fade
comment:
The Stereo X-Fade lets you crossfade two stereo tracks. Use the two controls to adjust the amount of each channel and shape your sound.

Features:
Modeled by x42
label: Stereo X-Fade

name: AMS Envelope
comment:
The AMS Env is a Control Voltage envelope module with added spice. It features extra parameters for hold and delay as well as a variable scale which scales the whole duration of the envelope.

Features:
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.
label: AMS Envelope

name: AMS LFO2 - Freq
comment:
The AMS LFO2 module is a Control Voltage LFO which offers a variety of waveforms: sine, triangle, sawtooth up, sawtooth down, square and Sample & Hold. It also has an input that can be used to reset the phase of the LFO, and a control to set the phase-angle.

Features:
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.
label: AMS LFO2 - Freq

name: AMS VCA Exp
comment:
The AMS VCA Exp module is an exponential Voltage Controlled Amplifier used for volume modulation. It allows you to, for instance, modulate the output of the AMS VCO3 using the control voltage signal of the AMS Env.

Features:
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.
label: AMS VCA Exp

name: AMS VCA Lin
comment:
The AMS VCA Lin module is a linear Voltage Controlled Amplifier used for volume modulation. It allows you to, for instance, modulate the output of the AMS VCO3 using the control voltage signal of the AMS Env.

Features: 
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.
label: AMS VCA Lin

name: AMS VCF
comment:
The AMS VCF module is a voltage controlled filter which offers a wide variety of filter types and flavours (multiple low-pass and band-pass flavours, as well as a high-pass and notch option). Additionally, it enables you to use other CV signals to modulate some of its features, such as frequency and resonance. 

Features: 
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.
label: AMS VCF

name: AMS VCO3
comment:
The AMS VCO3 is an oscillator module which can generate multiple waveforms (sine, square, triangle, sawtooth). Additionally, it features CV inputs that can be used for frequency and pulse-width modulation, as well as a Sync input which allows for various types of oscillator sync sounds. 

Features: 
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.
label: AMS VCO3

name: GxCreamMachine
comment:
Inspired by the Hughes & Kettner Cream Machine, a miniature guitar tube amp used to produce the classic over-driven British Rock tone,  the GxCreamMachine is an analogue simulation of a full stage power amp which will allow you to easily feed your signal into a PA system. Control compression and saturation with the “level” knob to get that creamy sound.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
(*)”Other product names modeled in the software trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD. Hughes & Kettner Cream Machine is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of the product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”
label: GxCreamMachine

name: GxKnightFuzz
comment:
The GxKnightFuzz is a distortion plugin based on the vintage Knight Fuzz KG-389 which was originally sold as a DIY kit in the mid 60s. This rarity was originally advertised as “The wildest sound you’ve ever heard” to an audience of young guitar geeks. And it delivers, to say the least! Its minimalistic interface allows you to achieve that rough, gritty fuzz while keeping the bottom-end fluid and not too muddy. The GxKnightFuzz is the perfect compromise between simplicity and versatility.

Features:

Modeled by Guitarix
label: GxKnightFuzz

name: GxAmplifier-X
comment:
The GxAmplifier-X is a do-it-all amplifier simulator based on some of the most famous tube amplifiers such as Fender, Mesa, Soldano, Vox and Marshall models. The ability to switch preamp and power amp tubes makes it an even more versatile amp. The built-in cabinet simulation eliminates the need of an additional cabinet simulator. Whether you are looking for a Fenderish sound, or a metal sound straight out of the eighties, the Gx-Amplifier-X will fulfill all your needs. 

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
label: GxAmplifier

name: GxAmplifier Stereo
comment:
Stereo version of the GxAmplifier-X

The GxAmplifier-X is a do-it-all amplifier simulator based on some of the most famous tube amplifiers such as Fender, Mesa, Soldano, Vox and Marshall models. The ability to switch preamp and power amp tubes makes it an even more versatile amp. The built-in cabinet simulation eliminates the need of an additional cabinet simulator. Whether you are looking for a Fenderish sound, or a metal sound straight out of the eighties, the Gx-Amplifier-X will fulfill all your needs. 

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
label: GxAmplifier ST

name: GxSVT
comment: Tube based bass pre-amp simulation
label: GxSVT

name: GxBaJaTubeDriver
comment:
The GxBajaTubeDriver is a tube distortion plugin based on the BK Butler 911 Tube Driver® (*). Originally put together in 1975 by keyboardist Brent Butler to be used as tube overdrive for his organ, the pedal found itself in the hands of a guitarist and the rest was history. It quickly became a favorite for many elite players thanks to its smooth distortion, its boost capabilities, but also its flexibility, as it can be used as a tone-shaper, a pre-amplifier or an extra amp channel. The GxBajaTubeDriver offers a variety of sounds, ranging from clean “Marshall in a can”, to fuller, thicker tones. 

Features: 
Modeled by Guitarix
(*) ”Other product names modeled in the software trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD. BK Butler 911 Tube Driver® is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of the product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”
label: GxBaJaTubeDriver

name: GxBoobTube
comment:
The BoobTube is a more versatile variation of the ValveCaster, a famous DIY guitar pedal schematic first put together in 2007 by Matsumin. The BoobTube offers a warm, harmonically rich range of tones, from bright fuzzes to darker distortions, without actually colouring the sound. The DIY project quickly became popular amongst sound enthusiasts searching for that tube-y goodness.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
label: GxBoobTube

name: GxBottleRocket
comment: Analogue simulation of a tube preamp pedal
label: GxBottleRocket

name: GxCompressor
comment:
"Compression (or more technically Dynamic range compression) is a subtle effect primarily for electric guitar where the highest and lowest points of the sound wave are "limited". This boosts the volume of softer picked notes, while capping the louder ones, giving a more even level of volume. This is frequently used in country music, where fast clean passages can sound uneven unless artificially 'squashed'." Wikipedia

*Unofficial documentation

source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compression_%28electric_guitar%29
label: GxCompressor

name: GxColorSoundTonebender
comment:
The ToneBender is modeled after the Colorsound ToneBender© (*).

The Colorsound ToneBender is a highly sought-after four transistor fuzz based on the original schematic of the Big Muff Pi. Nonetheless, it has its own unique sound which is often brighter. With its own bank of notable users such as Jack White, Jimmy Page and Pete Townshend, this pedal became an icon of its own.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix

(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
The Colorsound Tone Bender© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”
label: GxCsTonebender

name: Gxdetune
comment:
A detuner with an octave option

*Unofficial documentation
label: Gxdetune

name: Gxduck_delay
comment:
The delayed signal added to output dependent of input signal amplitude. 
If the input signal is high. The delayed signall turned off, and vise versa.
The switching controlled by envelope follower

*Unofficial documentation
label: Gxduck_delay

name: Gxduck_delay_st
comment:
The delayed signal added to output dependent of input signal amplitude. 
If the input signal is high. The delayed signall turned off, and vise versa.
The switching controlled by envelope follower
label: Gxduck_delay_st

name: GxExpander
comment:
"The expander is a compressor in reverse. There are two types of expander. In some, signals above the threshold remain at unity gain whereas signals below the threshold are reduced in gain, whereas in others the signal above the threshold also has the gain increased. Therefore you can use an expander as a noise reduction unit. Set the threshold to be just below the level of the player when playing. When the player stops the signal will fall below this threshold and the signal is reduced in gain thus reducing the noise or spill."

*Unofficial documentation

source: http://www.sae.edu/reference_material/audio/pages/Compression.htm
label: GxExpander

name: GxFlanger
comment:
"Flanging /ˈflændʒɪŋ/ is an audio effect produced by mixing two identical signals together, one signal delayed by a small and gradually changing period, usually smaller than 20 milliseconds. This produces a swept comb filter effect: peaks and notches are produced in the resulting frequency spectrum, related to each other in a linear harmonic series. Varying the time delay causes these to sweep up and down the frequency spectrum. A flanger is an effects unit that creates this effect.

Part of the output signal is usually fed back to the input (a "re-circulating delay line"), producing a resonance effect which further enhances the intensity of the peaks and troughs. The phase of the fed-back signal is sometimes inverted, producing another variation on the flanging sound." Wikipedia

*Unofficial documentation

source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flanging
label: GxFlanger

name: GxFuzzMaster
comment:
The GxFuzzMaster is modeled after the Vintage Fuzz Master© (*).

The Vintage Fuzz Master© (*) is a really wild fuzz that gives back to the fuzz sound that was heard in the most insane Jimi Hendrix performances, or psychedelic noise freak outs of the 60’s and 70’s. Most of these sounds were created by combining multiple fuzz faces and/or tone benders with a high gain stack. The Vintage Fuzz master puts all of this in one tiny package. All the madness of a vintage fuzz without the hassle of carrying a stack with you.

comment:
The Gx FuzzFace FullerMod is modeled after the classic Fuzz Face pedal(*), but with the Fuller Mods. 

The classical Fuzz Face originated in 1966. Back then, the pedal did not get that much attention as it lacked the very popular tube sound. Nowadays, it is considered a classic thanks to Jimi Hendrix using it extensively.

The classic Fuzz Face has two controls: Volume and Fuzz. Now, with the Fuller mods 2, further controls are introduced. The input and drive knobs are used in order to  “clean” up the distortion that the Fuzz Face produces, crafting more subtle shades of softer distortion.

name: GxScreamingBird
comment:
The Gx Screaming Bird is modeled after the Electro-Harmonix Screaming Bird treble booster (*)

Do your solos get lost in the mix? Boost your way to the top! Rather then turning up the volume, the ScreamingBird might be just what you need. The ScreamingBird treble booster is meant for boosting the high frequencies of your guitar signal while also adding a tiny bit of distortion to the sound. 

It became most popular in the 1960’s when mostly used to overdrive the dark sounding British tube amps. Since then, it has been used by a variety of musicians such as Eric Claption, Tony Iommi, Ritchie Blackmore, Brian May and Marc Bolan. 

A really straightforward pedal with only one knob. Simply set it to the desired amount of boost and you are good to go.

name: Gxshimmizita
comment:
The GxShimmizita provides several reverb flavors of the shimmer type. It does so by being part pitch-shifter and part convolution-reverb.

Expect strange sounds as if from outer space, drifting reverbs and arpeggiator-like pitch runs. On more mild settings it can function as a straightforward reverb that works especially well on guitar and synthesizers.

The Pitch Shift control determines how much the pitch will be shifted up or down. This pitch can be modulated by an LFO, an envelope or a blend of both. Use the Mod Source control to select this blend and use the LFO Speed and Env Time parameters to set the rate of modulation.

The reverb tone can be controlled by Freq Low and Freq High. The individual high and low components have their own Decay parameters. The Mix control sets the blend between the dry signal and the fully processed signal.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
label: Gxshimmizita

name: GxTiltTone
comment:
The GxTiltTone is a very simple and effective Tilt Tone control.

A Tilt Tone control is a kind of tone control that is quite rare to come across and most people only know it from the Quad 34 Hi-Fi© (*) pre-amp. Unlike the typical tone control that boosts or cuts only the highs, mids or lows, a Tilt Tone shifts both highs and lows at once. Meaning that turning the Tone knob to the left will boost your bass but also cut your treble.

The Drive is used to set the pre-gain, and when set high enough, it will start to distort. The level control is used for the overall volume of the pedal.

Features:
Modeled by Guitarix
(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.

name: GxTubeScreamer
comment:
The GxTubeScreamer is an analog distortion emulation of the classic Ibanez TS-9© (*).

First released in 1982 this is a real classic among all musicians. The pedal mimics the sound of a vintage tube amplifier, and has a characteristic mid-boosted tone which is popular amongst blues and rock players. The legendary Tube Screamer has been used by countless guitarists to create their signature sound, and is one of the most successful, widely copied and "modded" overdrive pedals in the history of the electric guitar.

It has a drive knob, a tone knob, and a level knob. The drive knob adjusts gain, the tone knob adjusts treble and the level knob adjusts the output volume of the pedal.

All IRs in this pack are forward audio's proprietary "Super-Blends": carefully crafted mixes of at least four microphones, and in some cases even dozens of different microphones on different speakers and cabinets.

Equipment used for the creation of the IRs:
Speakers: Celestion™ Vintage V30, Celestion™ G12-T75, Celestion™ G12M-25 Greenback Anz.
Cabinets: Marshall™ 1960A 1995 Limited Edition Red (Closed Back) 4x12 angled box,
Grossmann™ SG-Box Isolationbox (4 channel custom)
Microphones: Shure™ SM57, Sennheiser™ MD421-HL (Vintage), Royer™ 121, Audix™ D2,
Neumann™ TLM102, Audiotechnica™ AT4050, Sennheiser™ MD421-U5,
Shure™ SM58, Shure™ SM7B, t-bone™ SCT800, Behringer™ ECM8000

name: Invada Compressor (mono)
comment:
The Invada Compressor is a very easy to use, high-quality relaxed compressor that features 6 knobs and a high level of controllability. 

A compressor reduces the level of an audio signal if its amplitude exceeds the set threshold. The gain reduction is determined by the ratio: a ratio of 4:1 means that if the input level is 4dB over the threshold, the output signal is 1dB over the threshold. 

The ‘Attack’ controls how quickly the compressor starts to act. the ‘Release’ is the period when the compressor gradually stops acting. The Knee controls whether the bend in the response curve between below threshold and above threshold is abrupt (hard) or graduated (soft).  

Features:
Modeled by Invada
label: Compressor M

comment:
The Invada Compressor is a very easy to use, high-quality relaxed compressor that features 6 knobs and a high level of controllability. 

A compressor reduces the level of an audio signal if its amplitude exceeds the set threshold. The gain reduction is determined by the ratio: a ratio of 4:1 means that if the input level is 4dB over the threshold, the output signal is 1dB over the threshold. 

The ‘Attack’ controls how quickly the compressor starts to act. the ‘Release’ is the period when the compressor gradually stops acting. The Knee controls whether the bend in the response curve between below threshold and above threshold is abrupt (hard) or graduated (soft).  

Features:
Modeled by Invada
label: Compressor St

name: Audio File
comment:
This is a simple audio file player plugin.

Just upload some files in the MOD file manager section (either loops, recordings or tracks) and load up the plugin.
Transport is rolling as long as the plugin is enabled and a file is selected.
You can also sync to host transport, which will play in frame-perfect sync, useful if you need a few loops playing together.

Files are streamed from disk if longer than 30 seconds in length, otherwise loaded entirely on RAM.

Even though this player plugin can loop files, it is not an audio looper.
Audio can loop back to the beginning if enabled, but it does not resample or pitch-shift to fit the host BPM.
The audio files are played back as-is, with resampling only done when needed to match the host sample rate.
label: Audio File

name: MIDI File
comment:
This is a simple MIDI file player plugin.

Just upload some files in the MOD file manager section (specifically MIDI songs) and load up the plugin.
Transport is rolling as long as the plugin is enabled and a file is selected.
You can also sync to host transport, so the player follows host start/stop controls.
When repeat mode is enabled, the player will restart playback from the beginning after playing the last MIDI event on the file.

Note that MIDI time is converted to wall-clock time, not beats or ticks.
This means the file is played exactly as it was made (as if in "song mode").
This ignores host BPM, as the plugin is intended to play full MIDI songs and not MIDI clips.
label: MIDI File

The Plate reverb is useful for a wide variety of sounds. It tends to get along very nicely with other reverbs or even drum kits!
Available in a stereo version.

comment:

comment:
The Scape delay looks like a straightforward delay pedal but there is more than meets the eye.
The Eighth, Triplet and Sixteenth settings from the drop down menu create a dotted sounding rhythm. 
The delayed sounds can be re-tuned with the Tune knob in the settings session. Set it to your standard tuning of 440Hz and hear a normal rhythmical sounding delay. Or use it to achieve some interesting modulated sounds. Each note will be slightly different, further increasing the uniqueness of this effect.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS
label: Scape

comment:

This pedal is mostly used to refresh the signal that has been subjected to low-quality analog equipment. This pedal features individual control over the low and high frequencies. Both have 3 knobs, one for the desired frequency on which the pedal should operate, one for the overall compression and one for the output gain of the frequency range.

A stereo version is available as SpiceX2.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS
label: Spice

name: ENG 212
comment:
The ENG 212 cabsim comes with 39 carefully captured impulse responses based on the Engl™ E 212VH. This cabinet is loaded with two Celestion™ Vintage 30 speakers, designed to handle high powered and overdriven amplifier sounds. It also features a closed back for a tight bass response. The cabinet is especially suited for high gain, rock and metal tones.

Each IR is available in three variations: Tube provides a warm low end response and subtle tube distortion, Solid (State) gives an uncolored representation of the cabinet and S.P.A.R.C. is a unique flavour with a balanced frequency response that helps you cut through the mix.

To create the impulses, the following microphones were used: Shure™ SM57, Sennheiser™ MD421-HL (Vintage), Audix™ D2, Audio-Technica™ AT4050, Sennheiser™ e609, AKG™ C414 B-ULS (Austrian made), Shure™ SM7B, Behringer™ ECM8000.

Features:
Impulse responses by forward audio
Plugin by MOD Devices

(*) "Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD. Celestion, Engl, Shure, AKG, Sennheiser, Audix, Audio-Technica, t-bone and Behringer are a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and were used merely to identify the products used in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders."
label: ENG 212

name: Marsh 1960
comment:
The Marsh 1960 cabsim comes with 39 carefully captured impulse responses based on the Marshall™ 1960A, the most iconic and best-selling guitar cabinet in history. It is equipped with 4 Celestion™ G12-T75 speakers, which are fantastic for any kind of rock sound.

AC/DC, Nirvana, Green Day, RHCP, Pearl Jam, Eric Clapton and a lot more artists have used this cabinet in their recordings for decades. The chance that one of your favorite records is made with a Marshall™ 1960 is close to 100%.
The impulse responses used for this plugin are not based on just any „normal" Marshall™ 1960A. It's the 1995 Limited Edition in red which was usually shipped with a Marshall™ JCM 800 head (also in red). Only 200 units of this particular type were produced.

To create the impulse responses, the following microphones were used: Shure™ SM57, Sennheiser™ MD421-HL (Vintage), Audix™ D2, Audiotechnica™ AT4050, Shure™ SM58, Shure™ SM7B, t-bone™ SCT800 and the Behringer™ ECM8000.

Features:
Impulse responses by forward audio
Plugin by MOD Devices
(*) "Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
Celestion, Marshall, Shure, Sennheiser, Audix, Audiotechnica, t-bone and Behringer are a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and were used merely to identify the products used in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders."

name: MEGA California Recto
comment:
The Mesa™ Boogie 4×12 Rectifier cabinet is probably  the most wanted guitar  cabinet of all time. Metallica, Foo Fighters, Soundgarden, Wes Borland -  the list of successful bands and guitarists using this cabinet is beyond comparison. Its tight attack paired with a powerful top end sound has shaped modern guitar sounds for the last 30 years. 

Four UK Made Celestion™ Vintage 30 speakers are loaded in this Mesa™ Boogie 4×12 Rectifier cab, which are carefully captured to spark in your mix! 

Each IR is available in three variations: Tube provides a warm low end response and subtle tube distortion, Solid (State) gives an uncolored representation of the cabinet and S.P.A.R.C. is a unique flavour with a balanced frequency response that helps you cut through the mix.

To create the impulses, the following microphones were used: ShureTM SM57, SennheiserTM MD421-HL (Vintage), AudixTM D2, AudiotechnicaTM AT4050, SennheiserTM e609, AKGTM C414 B-ULS (Austrian made), ShureTM SM7B, t-boneTM SCT800, BehringerTM ECM8000

Features:
Impulse responses by forward audio
Plugin by MOD Devices

Celestion, Marshall, Shure, Sennheiser, Audix, Audiotechnica, t-bone and Behringer are a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and were used merely to identify the products used in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders."

name: MDA Ambience
comment:
The Ambience aims to emulate the sonic properties of a room. By tweaking the damping or roomsize controls, add some texture and reverb to your sound.

Features:
Modeled by MDA
label: Ambience

name: MDA BeatBox
comment:
Contains three samples (kick, snare and hat) designed to be triggered by incoming audio in three frequency ranges.  The default samples are based on the Roland CR-78.

To record your own sounds, use the Record control to monitor the plug's input, then with the source stopped select the slot to record into, play your sound, then with the source stopped again, switch back to monitoring.  This process is easier in an 'off line' editor such as WaveLab, rather than during a live mixdown in a DAW.
label: BeatBox

name: MDA DX10
comment:
The DX10 is inspired by the later Yamaha DX© (*) synthesizers which are some of the most popular digital synths in the world. This generator, however, was tweaked a bit to give it a warmer cleaner tone. It is 8-voice polyphonic and has a wide variety of sounds and presets. Some of these are bound to give you flashbacks to the 80’s where the DX series really shined!

Features:
Modeled by MDA
(*) “Other product names modeled in the software trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD. Yamaha DX© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of the product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”
label: DX10

name: MDA Detune
comment:
The Detune is a low-quality stereo pitch shifter. It can be used for the sort of detune effects found on multi-effects. It will create a widening effect but wont ‘swoosh’ like a chorus. 
This effect was very popular in the 80’s with bands such as Boston and Judas Priest, but Ozzy Osbourne is also known for using detuning on his vocals. 

Features:
Modeled by MDA
label: Detune

name: MDA DubDelay
comment:
The DubDelay is the go-to pedal for musicians who look for a delay pedal that adds something special to their sound.
The unique features of the DubDelay are its LFO and Pitch effect, and the modulation it creates. Perfect for clean sounds where you would want to add a vibrato-like effect to the mix. Or change the Pitch to create sounds you have never heard before.

Features:
Modeled by MDA
label: DubDelay

name: MDA ePiano
comment:
The ePiano is based around 12 carefully sampled and mastered Rhodes© Piano (*) samples.
Rhodes© Pianos are electrical instruments that were designed in the 40’s but only became popular in the 70’s. Instead of using strings to produce sound, it uses tin metal tines which are then amplified through an electrical pickup.

The modulation parameter is used to set the modulation depth and the modulation mode. If the modulation control is set to a negative value the LFO will be modulating panning. If it's set to a positive value it will modulate the volume, resulting in a classic tremolo effect.

Features:
Modeled by MDA
(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
Rhodes© Pianos are a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and were used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”
label: ePiano

name: MDA JX10
comment:
The JX10 is a polyphonic synthesizer with high-quality output and lot of options to modulate the filter. This can be done with both the envelope and/or the LFO.
Due to all its controls, this synthesizer gives you flexibility to create a vast variety of sounds. Or just to find some kick-ass tones among the presets.

Features:
Modeled by MDA
label: JX10

comment: No overdrive or speaker cabinet simulation is added - you may want to combine this plug-in with Combo.  For a much thicker sound try combining two Leslie plug-ins in series!

comment:
The Overdrive effect has a variety of sonic possibilities: adding body to drum loops, fuzz guitar, as well as that typical muffled “standing outside of a nightclub” sound. A simple, straight-forward yet versatile tool.

Features:
Modeled by MDA
